result.markdown:
--- title: "Diving deeper with Palmer Penguins
End of video" execute: warning: false fig-width: 6 fig-asp: 0.618 --- # Introduction How do sizes of penguins vary across species, islands, and sexes? What about other characteristics? ## Packages We will use the **tidyverse** and **ggbeeswarm** packages for data wrangling and visualization and the **palmerpenguins** package for the data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(palmerpenguins) library(ggbeeswarm) ``` ::: ## Data The dataset we will visualize is called `penguins`. Let's `glimpse()` at it. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glimpse(penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 344 Columns: 8 $ species Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adel… $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgerse… $ bill_length_mm 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3, 38.9, 39.2, 34.1, … $ bill_depth_mm 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6, 17.8, 19.6, 18.1, … $ flipper_length_mm 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181, 195, 193, 190, 186… $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650, 3625, 4675, 3475, … $ sex male, female, female, NA, female, male, female, male… $ year 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007… ``` ::: ::: # Visualizing penguin weights ## Single variable ::: callout-note Analyzing the a single variable is called **univariate** analysis. ::: Create visualizations of the distribution of `weight`s of penguins. ### Exercise 1 Make a histogram. Set an appropriate binwidth. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g)) + geom_histogram(binwidth = 250) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/histogram-weight-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ### Exercise 2 Make a boxplot. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g)) + geom_boxplot() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/boxplot-weight-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ### Exercise 3 Based on these, determine if each of the following statements about the shape of the distribution is true or false. - The distribution of penguin weights in this sample is left skewed. **FALSE** - The distribution of penguin weights in this sample is unimodal. **Difficult to determine, FALSE** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g)) + geom_density() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ## Two variables ::: callout-note Analyzing the relationship between two variables is called **bivariate** analysis. ::: Create visualizations of the distribution of `weight`s of penguins by `species`. ### Exercise 4 Make a single histogram. Set an appropriate binwidth. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, fill = species)) + geom_histogram(binwidth = 250) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/histogram-weight-species-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ### Exercise 5 Use multiple histograms via faceting, one for each species. Set an appropriate binwidth, add color as you see fit, and turn off legends if not needed. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, fill = species)) + geom_histogram(binwidth = 250) + facet_wrap(~species, ncol = 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/histogram-weight-species-facet-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ### Exercise 6 Use side-by-side box plots. Add color as you see fit and turn off legends if not needed. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, y = species, fill = species)) + geom_boxplot(show.legend = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/boxplot-weight-species-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ### Exercise 7 Use density plots. Add color as you see fit. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, fill = species, color = species)) + geom_density(alpha = 0.5) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/density-weight-species-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ### Exercise 8 Use violin plots. Add color as you see fit and turn off legends if not needed. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, y = species, color = species, fill = species)) + geom_violin(alpha = 0.2, show.legend = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/violin-weight-species-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ### Exercise 9 Make a jittered scatter plot. Add color as you see fit and turn off legends if not needed. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(1234) ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_jitter(alpha = 0.5) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/jitter-weight-species-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ### Exercise 10 Use beeswarm plots. Add color as you see fit and turn off legends if not needed. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g, color = species, shape = species)) + geom_beeswarm(show.legend = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/beeswarm-weight-species-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ### Exercise 11 Use multiple geoms on a single plot. Be deliberate about the order of plotting. Change the theme and the color scale of the plot. Finally, add informative labels. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, y = species, color = species)) + geom_boxplot() + geom_beeswarm() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/multi-geoms-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ## Multiple variables ::: callout-note Analyzing the relationship between three or more variables is called **multivariate** analysis. ::: ### Exercise 12 Facet the plot you created in the previous exercise by `island`. Adjust labels accordingly. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, y = species, color = species)) + geom_boxplot(show.legend = FALSE) + geom_beeswarm(show.legend = FALSE) + facet_wrap(~island, ncol = 1) + labs( x = "Weight (grams)", y = "Species", title = "Weights of penguins across species and islands" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](3-3-diving-deeper-palmer-penguins-eov_files/figure-html/multi-geoms-facet-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: Before you continue, let's turn off all warnings the code chunks generate and resize all figures. We'll do this by editing the YAML. # Visualizing other variables ### Exercise 13 Pick a single categorical variable from the data set and make a bar plot of its distribution. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # add code here ``` ::: ### Exercise 14 Pick two categorical variables and make a visualization to visualize the relationship between the two variables. Along with your code and output, provide an interpretation of the visualization. Add interpretation here. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # add code here ``` ::: ### Exercise 15 Make another plot that uses at least three variables. At least one should be numeric and at least one categorical. In 1-2 sentences, describe what the plot shows about the relationships between the variables you plotted. Don't forget to label your code chunk. Add interpretation here. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # add code here ``` :::
